theater

Class Play.Character<A extends Actor<P>>

  • java.lang.Object
    • theater.Play.Character<A>
  • Type Parameters:
    A - the Actor class to run the role described by this character. The actor stores the local state of the protocol and gives access to the runtime environment.
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    Play.StatelessCharacter
    Enclosing class:
    Play<P>

    protected class Play.Character<A extends Actor<P>>
extends java.lang.Object
    Implements a representation of a character in a play. A character can send things, run things and test things.
    Author:
    rongomai
    See Also:
    Actor

    • Field Detail

      • characterName

        final java.lang.String characterName

    • Constructor Detail

      • Character

        public Character(java.lang.Class<?> characterActorClass,
                 java.lang.String characterName)
        Creates a new character in the play.
        Parameters:
        characterActorClass - the class object of the Actor class given in the template parameter of this class. This is necessary because of Java's irritating type erasure mechanism.
        characterName - an intuitive name for the character (like "alice", "bob" or "server") to be used as the character's identifier with Play.interpretAs(String). It must be unique in the play.

    • Method Detail

      • run

        public void run(RunnableWithActor<A> run)
        Makes the character run a set of actions.
        Parameters:
        run - a lambda expression defining the actions to be run.
        See Also:
        run(RunnableWithActor, String)

      • run

        public void run(RunnableWithActor<A> run,
                java.lang.String runName)
        Makes the character run a set of actions.
        Parameters:
        run - a lambda expression defining the actions to be run.
        runName - a name to identify the run. This should be used when passing the same lambda expression (same reference) twice in the Play scene. The name avoids both calls to run from being indistinguishable.
        See Also:
        run(RunnableWithActor)

      • test

        public boolean test(TestableWithActor<A> test)
        Make the character run a set of actions whose outcome is a boolean. This method is to be used inside flux control structures, such as whiles and ifs.
        Parameters:
        test - the test to be performed.
        Returns:
        the value of the test (it's actually more complicated than that, but never mind).

      • test

        public boolean test(TestableWithActor<A> test,
                    java.lang.String testName)
        Make the character run a set of actions whose outcome is a boolean. This method is to be used inside flux control structures, such as whiles and ifs.
        Parameters:
        test - the test to be performed.
        testName - a name to identify the test. This should be used when passing the same lambda expression (same reference) twice in the Play scene. The name avoids both calls to test from being indistinguishable.
        Returns:
        the value of the test (it's actually more complicated than that, but never mind).
        See Also:
        test(TestableWithActor)

      • send

        public void send(Play.Character<?> receiver,
                 java.lang.String name)
          throws SendException,
                 ReceiveException
        Makes the character send a message to another character.
        Parameters:
        receiver - the receiving character.
        name - the message's name (e.g., "ack").
        Throws:
        SendException - in case message cannot be sent by any reason.
        ReceiveException - in case the sender discovers the message was not received by any reason.
        See Also:
        #send(Character, String, int)

      • send

        public <B extends Actor<P>> void send(Play.Character<B> receiver,
                                      SupplierWithActor<P,A> onSend,
                                      ConsumerWithActor<P,B> onReceive,
                                      java.lang.String name)
        Makes the character send a message to another character. The content of the message is generated by onSend at the sender side and is processed by onReceive at the receiver side.
        Parameters:
        receiver - the receiving character.
        onSend - a lambda expression taking a sending Actor object and returning the content of the message to be sent.
        onReceive - a lambda expression taking a receiving Actor object and the content of the message to be received.
        name - the name of the message.
        Throws:
        SendException - in case message cannot be sent by any reason.
        ReceiveException - in case the sender discovers the message was not received by any reason.
        See Also:
        #send(Character, SupplierWithActor, String), #send(Character, SupplierWithActor, String, int), #send(Character, ConsumerWithActor, String), #send(Character, ConsumerWithActor, String, int), #send(Character, SupplierWithActor, ConsumerWithActor, String, int)

      • send

        public void send(Play.Character<?> receiver,
                 SupplierWithActor<P,A> onSend,
                 java.lang.String name)
        Makes the character send a message to another character. The content of the message is generated by onSend at the sender side.
        Parameters:
        receiver - the receiving character.
        onSend - a lambda expression taking a sending Actor object and returning the content of the message to be sent.
        name - the name of the message.
        Throws:
        SendException - in case message cannot be sent by any reason.
        ReceiveException - in case the sender discovers the message was not received by any reason.
        See Also:
        #send(Character, SupplierWithActor, String, int), #send(Character, ConsumerWithActor, String), #send(Character, ConsumerWithActor, String, int), #send(Character, SupplierWithActor, ConsumerWithActor, String), #send(Character, SupplierWithActor, ConsumerWithActor, String, int)

      • send

        public <Q extends Actor<P>> void send(Play.Character<Q> receiver,
                                      ConsumerWithActor<P,Q> onReceive,
                                      java.lang.String name)
        Makes the character send a message to another character. The content of the message is processed by onReceived at the receiver side.
        Parameters:
        receiver - the receiving character.
        onReceive - a lambda expression taking a receiving Actor object and the content of the message to be received.
        name - the name of the message.
        Throws:
        SendException - in case message cannot be sent by any reason.
        ReceiveException - in case the sender discovers the message was not received by any reason.
        See Also:
        #send(Character, SupplierWithActor, String), #send(Character, SupplierWithActor, String, int), #send(Character, ConsumerWithActor, String, int), #send(Character, SupplierWithActor, ConsumerWithActor, String), #send(Character, SupplierWithActor, ConsumerWithActor, String, int)

      • send

        public void send(Play.Character<?> receiver,
                 java.lang.String name,
                 int timeout)
          throws SendException,
                 ReceiveException
        Same as #send(Character, String), but allows specifying a timeout, after which the message will no longer be received (a SendException might be raised if the character is unable to proceed without this message).
        Parameters:
        receiver - the receiving character's character object.
        name - the message's name (e.g., "ack").
        timeout - the timeout, expressed in milliseconds.
        Throws:
        SendException - in case message cannot be sent by any reason.
        ReceiveException - in case the sender discovers the message was not received by any reason.
        See Also:
        #send(Character, String)

      • send

        public <Q extends Actor<P>> void send(Play.Character<Q> receiver,
                                      SupplierWithActor<P,A> onSend,
                                      ConsumerWithActor<P,Q> onReceive,
                                      java.lang.String name,
                                      int timeout)
        Same as #send(Character, SupplierWithActor, ConsumerWithActor, String, int), timeout, after which the message will no longer be received (a SendException might be raised if the character is unable to proceed without this message).
        Parameters:
        receiver - the receiving character.
        onSend - a lambda expression taking a sending Actor object and returning the content of the message to be sent.
        onReceive - a lambda expression taking a receiving Actor object and the content of the message to be received.
        name - the name of the message.
        timeout - the timeout expressed in milliseconds.
        Throws:
        SendException - in case message cannot be sent by any reason.
        ReceiveException - in case the sender discovers the message was not received by any reason.
        See Also:
        #send(Character, SupplierWithActor, ConsumerWithActor, String)

      • send

        public void send(Play.Character<?> receiver,
                 SupplierWithActor<P,A> onSend,
                 java.lang.String name,
                 int timeout)
        Same as #send(Character, SupplierWithActor, String), but allows specifying a timeout, after which the message will no longer be received (a SendException might be raised if the character is unable to proceed without this message).
        Parameters:
        receiver - the receiving character.
        onSend - a lambda expression taking a sending Actor object and returning the content of the message to be sent.
        name - the name of the message.
        timeout - the timeout expressed in milliseconds.
        Throws:
        SendException - in case message cannot be sent by any reason.
        ReceiveException - in case the sender discovers the message was not received by any reason.
        See Also:
        #send(Character, SupplierWithActor, String)

      • send

        public <Q extends Actor<P>> void send(Play.Character<Q> receiver,
                                      ConsumerWithActor<P,Q> onReceive,
                                      java.lang.String name,
                                      int timeout)
        Same as #send(Character, ConsumerWithActor, String), timeout, after which the message will no longer be received (a SendException might be raised if the character is unable to proceed without this message).
        Parameters:
        receiver - the receiving character.
        onReceive - a lambda expression taking a receiving Actor object and the content of the message to be received.
        name - the name of the message.
        timeout - the timeout expressed in milliseconds.
        Throws:
        SendException - in case message cannot be sent by any reason.
        ReceiveException - in case the sender discovers the message was not received by any reason.
        See Also:
        #send(Character, ConsumerWithActor, String)

      • query

        public <Q extends Actor<P>> void query(Play.Character<Q> receiver,
                                       UnaryWithActor<P,Q> process,
                                       java.lang.String queryName)
        Makes the character query another character. The queried character receives the query messages, processes it and sends a response back to the querier.
        Parameters:
        receiver - the queried character.
        process - a lambda expression taking a queried Actor object and the query message content and returning the response message content.
        queryName - the name of the query.
